title: 112_s25
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Unfair Giveaways and Restrictions Act of 2011" or "SUGAR Act of 2011". It pertains to the Sugar Program. The "Stop Unfair Giveaways and Restrictions Act of 2011" or "SUGAR Act of 2011" amends the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 by phasing out loan rates for sugar beets and sugarcane crops, progressively reducing them to $0 by 2015. Effective from the 2015 crop onwards, the SUGAR Act of 2011 repeals section 156 of the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996, eliminating loan rates for sugar beets and sugarcane crops. The SUGAR Act of 2011 eliminates sugar price support and production adjustment programs. The SUGAR Act of 2011 eliminates sugar price support and production adjustment programs. Processor of 2015 or later sugarcane or sugar beets crops cannot get loans or price support from the Secretary of Agriculture using specific funds. Marketing quotas and allotments under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 are repealed. The Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 is amended to remove support for sugar cane and sugar beets. Section 32 activities and powers of the commodity credit corporation are also adjusted. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to remove support for sugar beets and sugarcane, and to include support for milk. Additionally, the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 is repealed, and permanent price support authority is suspended and repealed. Storage facility loans under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 are also addressed. The Feedstock Flexibility Program for bioenergy producers under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is repealed, starting from the 2013 crop of sugar beets and sugarcane. Transition provisions ensure that the changes do not affect liability under previous laws. SEC. 4. TARIFF-RATE QUOTAS. The Secretary of Agriculture must establish a program by October 1, 2011, to increase tariff-rate quotas for raw cane sugar and refined sugars to support a competitive sugar processing industry and ensure an adequate sugar supply at reasonable prices in the United States. Factors considered include the quantity and quality of sugar for human consumption and available from domestic processing of sugarcane and sugar beets. The Secretary of Agriculture must establish a program by October 1, 2011, to increase tariff-rate quotas for raw cane sugar and refined sugars to support a competitive sugar processing industry and ensure an adequate sugar supply at reasonable prices in the United States. Factors considered include the quantity of sugar for reasonable carryover stocks, availability from carryover stocks for human consumption, and consistency with international agreements. Specialty sugar is exempt from this program. Definitions for "quota year" and "human consumption" are provided. SEC. 5. APPLICATION. This Act and its amendments will apply starting from the 2012 crop of sugar beets and sugarcane.
